Long time Windows exposes UAC virtualization for registry keys and file system. 
If we could use it it would solve this problem.
@iSazonov that would potentially work for Windows, but doesn't solve the same problem with Snaps.

I like the way for Windows. I think it is right way. 
I guess there is a solution in Snaps too - PowerShell is not single application with such behavior. My quick search https://forum.snapcraft.io/t/snap-layouts/7207 "Creating new files and directories in read-only spaces". So I believe Snaps has that we need.
What parts of snap would we map?  Just because we can, doesn't mean we should.  We should not make any part of $PSHome writable on linux.
See also https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell-Snap/issues/32
Can we just use `/etc/` for this? Or does Snap "classic" et al not have a way to do this?
@joeyaiello The problem is this should be done in PowerShell. `/etc` is where the file should be for all PowerShell installations.
For reference #4080

## Proposal

### Rational

It looks like the majority of the problem is writing to the configuration file.  We should move it under `/etc` for Linux and macOS, and `%programdata% for Windows.

We can make similar changes for `$PSHome\SessionConfig` and `$PSHome\en-US` (and related folders) later.

### Details

#### Security

These folders should be secured similarly to the currently location the file is located at when the product is installed via DEB, RPM, or MSI.

The configuration file is system wide configuration and only system administrators should be able to modify it.  This also eliminates pwsh creating it on first launch.

#### Linux and macOS

We would move the system configuration to `/etc/powershell/powershell.config.json`
We would use the folder so that any addition items will be group together.

Packages would have to be updated to create this and the zip instruction would have to be update or a script created.

#### Windows

We would move the system configuration to `%programdata%\Microsoft\PowerShell\powershell.config.json`

MSI could be update to create the file.
MSIX - @stevel-msft?
zip - instructions would have to be updated

### Issues

1. What do you do on upgrade?  Currently we overwrite the file, but this is not the correct behavior.
2. Not sure how to set the default config after MSIX install.
   * Possible solution is to include a script that admins can run after install.  This would simplify zip and tar.gz install as well.
For PowerShell.config.json, it might be better to have cmdlet(s) to manage that file with `-Scope AllUsers/CurrentUser`.  This would work cross-platform.
Cmdlets is an option. The presence of configs implies supporting direct editing.

@TravisEz13 system wide config can exist, but needs to be under ProgramData (on Windows) and requires elevation to set.  My point of the cmdlets isn't for setting individual settings, but something like `Get-PowerShellConfig` which returns an object representing the config and `Set-PowerShellConfig` to save it, but with `-Scope` parameter so the user doesn't need to know where in the filesystem it goes.

> We would move the system configuration to /etc/powershell/powershell.config.json
We would move the system configuration to %programdata%\Microsoft\PowerShell\powershell.config.json

This means different versions of `pwsh` will share the same configuration file, which is problematic. Even with sub-folder named after the version, it means different instances of the same version will share the same configuration file, which is still a breaking change from today's behavior.

@SteveL-MSFT I still don't see how this addresses this issue at all.  I think you have a fundamental mis-understanding of the problem.  That might be a useful new feature, but it doesn't help solve this problem.
@daxian-dbw System wide configuration should be actually system wide, this is a reason to move it into a common folder.  I can see reason to have different files for preview and stable.

@PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this, we agree not to take any changes for RC.  We should relnote the limitations and address post 7.0.  The proposal moving the system level config to /etc and %programdata% makes sense.

In last days I make some experiments with the config and new Core Json API (to remove dependency from Newtonsoft Json.NET) and discover some inconsistencies in the config file format and serialization/deserialization. I hope we fix this too in 7.1.

I think we need to make this a priority for 7.1, but particularly implementing the `/etc/powershell/powershell.config.json` . The scenario is essentially that, as on Windows with the GP store, Unix admins need to be confident that Computer-wide Policy is applied to all PowerShells on a box, irrespective of whether they were bin-dropped as portable copies or installed to XDG-compliant locations via a package.

I can follow up with offline justification if needed

Now .Net Core 5.0 has new enhancements in JSON implementation and this raises a question - will we move on .Net Core 5.0 in 7.1 timeframe and benefit from new .Net Core enhancements and improvements? 
PowerShell Core 7.0 LTS is based on .Net Core 3.1 LTS - release in 2020 year
PowerShell Core 7.1 GA is based on .Net Core 5.0 GA - release in 2021 year
PowerShell Core 8.0 LTS is based on .Net Core 6.0 LTS - release in 2022 year
@iSazonov the plan is to move to .NET 5 for 7.1 as soon as they have a public preview.
@SteveL-MSFT - would you release a 7.1 on a pre-release version of .NET core 5?
@doctordns Release 7.1 will be on release .Net Core 5.
